bibl.title: Biography of Roger Post Ames, by [Jessie Daniel Ames?], [19--]

div1.p: This biography focuses on the reasons why Ames should be included with the Yellow Fever Board and the volunteer soldiers in the Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Biography of Roger Post Ames, by [Jessie Daniel Ames?], [19--]
div1.p:
Roger P. Ames was born in New Orleans. 1870 Graduated Medical
Department, Tulane University, in 1890. Resident physician U. S.
Engineer department, 4th Engineer district, Mississippi River Commis-
sion in 1891. Quarantine Officer of State Board of Health of Louisi-
ana in 1892 and 1893. Was in private practice in New Orleans from
1894 to 1898, and during this time was physician to the Incurable
Home, New Orleans, and visiting physician to Turo Infirmary. Was
resident physician at this Infirmary during yellow fever epidemic at
New Orleans in August, September, October, and part of November, 1897.

Became Contract Surgeon U. S. Army, May 12, 1898, during
Spanish-American war at Mobile, Ala. Assigned to 19th Regiment U. S.
Infantry as Senior Surgeon (being the only surgeon in command) from
May 14 to July 12, 1898, was in camp at Mobile, Alabama, and Tampa,
Fla.

Ordered in July 1898 to Santiago, Cuba. On arrival assign-
ed to duty with 10th regiment, U. S. Infantry, relieving Major S. I.
Robinson, Senior Surgeon with command from July 19 to November, 1898.
In camp at Santiago, Cuba, Montauk, N. Y., and Huntsville, Ala. Con-
tract annulled at his request.

Re-entered the service April 15, 1899 and was ordered to
Havana, Cuba. There he was assigned to Military Hospital No. 1, and
was given special duty connected with the sanitary work at the Palace,
Havana. On various occasions was ordered to special work connected
with the diagnosis of yellow fever cases, inspections, etc. On dis-
continuance of Military Hospital No. 1 was ordered, April 11, 1900
to Columbia Barracks. While at Columbia Barracks he was in charge
of the yellow fever wards at the Post Hospital during the yellow
fever epidemic at Quenados, near the post. It was here that he took
Page #2.
part in the notable experiments as to the source and cause of yellow
fever under Major Walter Reed. On account of his previous experience
with yellow fever he was made the resident physician of the yellow
fever hospital and the yellow fever experimental camp. Regarding
this he says in a memorandum of his own: “While at this station it
was my peculiar good fortune to study yellow fever in its very earli-
est stages, and to see the mosquito theory, under the wise adminis-
tration of the Medical Department, U. S. Army, fully demonstrated;
and at the same time having the honor of treating the experimental
cases, two of which cases were members of the Medical Department Com-
mission.

When the experimental station, Camp Lazear, was opened,
I was placed in immediate charge, under the direction of Major Reed,
President of the Commission. The work of this Commission and the
wisdom of the one ordering same, is of national record, and the
result only second to the discovery of anesthesia. The clinical
and other bedside record work for this distinguished Commission was
performed by me. On many occasions, both verbally and in writing,
the President of this Commission has expressed himself fully appre-
ciating the high character of my work and assistance rendered him
in the investigations.”

While treating these cases Dr. Ames was stricken with
yellow fever in the latter part of January 28, 1901.

On January 24, 1902 was made Assistant Surgeon of Volun-
teers U. S. Army with rank of Captain, and on January 28, 1902 was
given rank of Major.

Was assigned to service in the Philippines with the Sixth
Page #3.
Separate Brigade, arriving in the Philippines early in 1902. Was
assigned to Oras, Samor, P. I., where he was made chief quarantine
officer in August, 1902.

Honorably discharged in February, 1903 and on his return
to the United States again became a Contract Surgeon, U. S. Army.
Was at Fort Barrancas, Fla., April 22, 1903. On September 29, 1903
was ordered to report for duty pertaining to yellow fever in vicinity
of Fort McIntosh, Texas. Referring to his work at Fort McIntosh the
Inspector General, Major J.D.C. Hoskins, made the following report in
June, 1904. “Contract Surgeon R. P. Ames, U.S.A. is the Post Surgeon.
Surgeon Ames seems to be very efficient in his administration of this
hospital. He is very active in his investigations about yellow fever
in the vicinity of the post. No deaths occurred at Fort McIntosh
from the yellow fever outbreak.

He was married to Miss Jessie Daniel of Texas in 1905 while
still serving in that state as Contract Surgeon. Was sent to Jackson
Barracks, New Orleans, La., when yellow fever broke out in that city
in 1905. Although the post was in the heart of the city his super-
visory work was so efficient that the epidemic did not reach the
troops, although the post was in a highly infected area.

Regarding the work of Dr. Ames at Fort McIntosh Passed
Assistant Surgeon Dr. T. D. Bevry said: “several cases occurred at
Fort McIntosh but all recovered.” From these cases Dr. Ames infected
mosquitoes and kept these infected mosquitoes alive on his own blood
until he could turn them over to Dr. Carroll who in his laboratory was
able to combat claims that had been made about the discovery of a para-
site. He joined the U. S. Public Health Service in 1906 or 1907 and
remained with it until his death in 1914. In that year he died while
fighting yellow fever in Central America.

Roger Post Ames, Surgeon in immediate command of Camp Lazear, was
on continuous service from November 20, 1900, when the Camp was opened
until February 28, 1901, when the Camp was closed. Not a single one
of the experimental cases died which remarkable record was attributed
to the unselfish devotion and scientific skill and knowledge of Dr.
Ames. Had there been the average mortality, twenty-five per cent
being the average, public condemnation would have been so severe that
the experiment would have had to be abandoned. There is no reported
record of another Surgeon in the Army who rendered the same service in
the same field. As the one surgeon upon whom Major Walter Reed looked
for this highly trained services, the name of Roger Post Ames should
be placed upon the Roll of Honor with the names of the Board and the
volunteer soldiers who committed their lives into the hands of Roger
Post Ames.

The Surgeon General of the Army in a report to Senator Steck,
Chairman of a sub-committee of the Committee on Military Affairs,
asserts that the services of Roger Post Ames in the yellow fever
experimental work in Cuba were only those required of him in “regular
line of duty” and that these services were merely routine and of no
greater value to the success of the experiment than those of orderlies
nurses, and hospital stewards; that therefore his name does not deserv
a place on the Roll of Honor created by Act of Congress, February 28,
1929.

Regular duty of Army Surgeons in times of peach consists of
attending “Sick calls” to which soldiers with ordinary ailments re-
port; visiting patients in hospital; and inspecting hospital;
giving orders for the day. Barracks hospitals have regularly est-
ablished quarters, not tents, under a military garrison.

Evidence which shows that services performed by Roger Post Ames
in Cuba were not regular and routine, but extraordinary, unusual and
of such importance as to merit placing his name on the Roll of Honor.

item.p:
A. Camp Lazear, itself, was not a barracks hospital to which
soldiers, regardless of their complaints, reported. It was a
specialty camp of tents created for one highly scientific and
dangerous experiment and the surgeons in charge of the camp had
to be scientifically trained, experienced, and equipped to carry out
the purposes of the experiment.

“This the second series of experiments began November 20, at
an experimental camp near Quemados, called Camp Lazear, and embraced
14 cases” - Senate Document #10, 59th Congress, 2nd Session, page_____

“A camp was especially constructed for the experiments about
four miles from Habana, christened Camp Lazear.” Senate Document
#10, 59th Congress, 2nd Session, Page 13.

“The necessity for an experimental camp became more imperative
as time passed. - - - We immediately set about choosing a location
for our camp. - - -on the twentieth of November we inaugurated our
camp which we named Camp Lazear in honor to the memory of our dead
colleague, consisting then of seven army tents guarded by a military
garrison.” Page 24 and 25 “Inside History of a Great Medical Dis-
covery” by Dr. Aristides Agramonte.

B Roger Post Ames was Surgeon in immediate command of Camp
Lazear because of his scientific fitness.

“Regarding his connection with the work of the Yellow Fever
Board, at the head of which was Major Walter Reed, the records show
that he (Dr. Ames) was on duty at Camp Lazear, the experimental camp
established by the Board, from the date of its establishment November
20, 1900, until February 28, 1901, on which date the Camp was dis-
continued.” Letter from G. H. Bridges (S) Major General, to Mrs.
Roger Post Ames, November 19, 1929.

“Dr. Ames had no connection with the yellow fever Board before
the establishment of Camp Lazear; he attended the cases of Drs. Car-
roll and Lazear when they came down with the fever in the regular
course of duty at Columbia Barracks.” Letter from Dr. Agramonte to
Mrs. Ames, May 27, 1930.

“Dr. Ames was Surgeon in immediate command of Camp Jesse W.
Lazear, United States Sanitary Experimental Station near Quemados.
And he was Attending Surgeon of the United States Army Yellow Fever
Commission. - - - A telephone connected Major Reed's room at Columbia
Barracks with Dr. Ames' tent at Camp Lazear.” Daily Picayune. New
Orleans, July 30, 1905. In re Yellow Fever Epidemic in that City to
which Dr. Ames had been sent to take charge of Jackson Barracks.
A scientific expert was grouped with Dr. Lazear by Major Reed.

“The cases studied during the Quemados epidemic had been diag-
nosed by a board of physicians selected largely by reason of their
familiarity with yellow fever. This Board consisted of Drs. Nicola
Silverio, Manuel Herera, Eduardo Angles, and acting Assistant Sur-
geon, Roger Post Ames and Jesse W. Lazear, U. S. Army Etiology of
Yellow Fever, page 4 - by Major Walter Reed.

C. Roger Post Ames was specially equipped to take charge of Camp
Lazear, and upon his scientific knowledge in carrying out the purposes
of Camp Lazear depended the success of the experiment and the demon-
stration of the theory on the Causation of Yellow Fever.

“His (Dr. Ames) scientific services began when a case developed;
as soon as high temperature or the least symptom appeared, the case -
- - - was placed under Dr. Ames' charge until his final recovery.
They all recovered, a fact that we all thought was a “feather in
his cap.” Italics Dr. Agramonte's in a letter to Mrs. Ames, May 27,
1930.

“This terminated our experiments with mosquitoes which the neces-
sarily performed on human beings, fortunately did not cause a single
death.” From Inside History of a Great Medical Discovery.” by Aris-
tides Agramonte.

“The highly dangerous character of these experiments and the good
fortune of the Board in its second and third series of cases is shown
by the fact that Dr. Guiteras, of Habana, in a series of seven cases,
innoculated in Habana lost three, bringing his experiments abruptly to
an end.” Page 3, Senate Document #10, 59th Congress, 2nd Session.
